Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of Democratic governors who have decided not to play football, stating that "three-fourths" of them have made this decision, without providing sufficient evidence or data to support this claim.
Understate: The claim understates the role of collegiate athletic conferences and universities in deciding whether their teams play football, instead attributing the decision solely to governors.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support or evidence to back up the statement that Republican governors have decided to play football while Democratic governors have decided not to play.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the decision to play or not play football is solely based on political affiliation, without considering other factors such as public health concerns or guidelines from health authorities.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim overlooks the possibility that the decision to play or not play football may be influenced by factors other than political affiliation, such as the prevalence of COVID-19 cases in the respective states.
